title: Insights into metabolic disease and ways to address them
content: Dr. Ronesh Sinha shares his insights into hyperinsulinemia, insulin resistance, metabolic dysregulation, inflammation, blood pressure, and obesity, and ways to address them with nutrition, sleep, exercise, stress management, and more.

title: Insulin resistant phenotypes and pathophysiology of metabolic syndrome
content: Dr. Sinha and Peter Attia discuss insulin resistant phenotypes, evolutionary theory, and geographic determinants of insulin resistance, which provide insight into the genetic architecture and pathophysiology of metabolic syndrome.

title: Stress and its impact on mental and physical health
content: Dr. Sinha and Peter Attia discuss the interrelated topic of stress, and how it might be inadvertently passed on to children, leading to mental and physical sickness down the road.

title: Ronesh's clinical treatment focus of metabolic illnesses in South and East Asian patient populations
content:
Realized there was a gap in resources between how physicians are educated and the populations most afflicted with metabolic diseases (e.g., insulin resistance, diabetes, cardiovascular disease)
Decided to create East and South Asian population-specific educational materials and protocols
Around the same time, Ronesh personally developed metabolic syndrome
Prompted him to step outside nutrition guidelines and look more closely at insulin resistance
He was following low fat, low-calorie model diet (eating meat, fish, healthy starch Bengal-style diet of his heritage)
Gradually tinkered with personal and patient macronutrient meal composition
Cut down on dietary CHO and prescribed more liberal dietary fat intake

title: The distinction between visceral fat and subcutaneous fat stores
content:
Three classifications of fat:
Superficial subcutaneous fat (adipose) tissue (SSCAT)
Deeper layer of subcutaneous adipose tissue (DSCAT), right underneath the skin
Visceral fat

title: Types of adipose tissue
content: The subcutaneous or “suburban” fat structures are organized and have less access to blood supply. Deeper tissue subcutaneous fat and visceral fat are less organized and have access to blood supply and to the liver. A study by Mitch Lazar that evaluated a combination resulting in four phenotypes: lean/overweight body weight with healthy/non-healthy metabolic markers, concluded that lean individuals with elevated metabolic markers had the worst outcomes (compared to overweight individuals who were also metabolically ill).

title: Body mass index (BMI) calculator for evaluating metabolic disease risk
content: Shortcomings of a body mass index (BMI) calculator for evaluating metabolic disease risk. Body type of South and East Asian men and women exemplify how physical appearance does not necessarily indicate metabolic health. Typically in men, unlike for women, the lack of subcutaneous fat insulation means that fat is predominantly stored as visceral fat.

title: Fatty liver and pre-prediabetes
content: Does Ronesh observe an association between patient TGs and their glycemic numbers? Fatty liver, elevated TGs, often with a family history of diabetes, but their glucose levels are fine (glucose tolerance). Important population to educate before becoming prediabetic: they still have preserved beta-cell function (as opposed to Beta-cell failure) and Hyperinsulinemia. When tested, usually present with high fasting insulin levels. The majority of the population that I see, they’ve already got fatty liver, they’ve got high triglycerides, but their glucose looks fine. And that is a really important population to really educate because I’m telling them now that you don’t have prediabetes, you have pre-prediabetes and this is where we can make the most impact.

title: Unified theory of metabolic disease
content: The difficulty in developing a unified theory of metabolic disease. Peter does not like the way diabetes is defined. The problem with Hemoglobin A1C. Using calibrated Dexcom (CGM) over the course of 90 days, he identifies patients’ average blood glucose. 75% of his patients have average blood glucose that does not match imputed average blood glucose. Peter himself is discordant (he hypothesizes due to his beta thalassemia minor) in that his hemoglobin A1C test overstates his average blood glucose compared to Continuous glucose monitor (CGM) reading. Peter does not consider test sensitive enough to evaluate more subtle hemoglobin A1C differences.

content:
Gamification and behavior modification
Becomes less about new insights

Hawthorne Effect in practice

title: Factors affecting blood glucose levels
content:
Ronesh observed, both personally and in his patients, that implementing nighttime rituals such as meditation and switching off devices, decreased fasting (morning) blood sugar
The liver dictates morning blood sugar and Cortisol impacts the liver
For individuals that are insulin resistant, liver is primed to produce high levels of glucose because of a high level of free fatty acids (FFAs) shuttled to liver to fuel gluconeogenesis
Ronesh observed an elevated morning glucose in patients when their diets were too low in CHO, especially in the evenings

title: Cortisol's role in blood glucose variability
content:
Cortisol and blood glucose variability [28:30]
Blood glucose improves with decrease in stress: The “emotional metabolic issue”
Cortisol plays an important role in fat flux through a fat cell
“I think cortisol is a vastly underappreciated regulator of fat flux through the fat cell. Insulin gets a lot of attention because it’s perhaps the most potent both on the side of lipolysis and Re-esterification.” – Peter Attia
Insulin’s role in elevated blood glucose: A symptom of metabolic syndrome [33:25]
⇒ For more on central paradox of insulin resistance check out a previous episode of The Drive with Jason Fung (specifically starting at 29:30)
Insulin gets a lot of the “credit” in the context of metabolic syndrome
Jason Fung’s model of insulin resistance explains that hyperinsulinemia rather than “resistance” drives metabolic syndrome
insulin receptors and/or intracellular mechanisms are not “broken”

title: Proposed diabetes diagnostic criteria
content:
Working towards a more robust diabetes diagnostic criteria, Peter proposes taking into account fasting and fed glucose levels, insulin levels, inflammatory markers
Peter has observed elevated night time glucose levels by CGM in heavier weight patients who are otherwise metabolically healthy: Could cortisol levels be responsible?

title: Regulation of hepatic glucose output
content:
The level of hepatic glucose output is tightly regulated
100 milligrams of circulating glucose (a teaspoon measure equivalent) separates a metabolically normal individual from someone with type 2 diabetes
An organism would die in a matter of minutes from Hypoglycemia after clamping the portal vein – thereby preventing the liver from circulating glucose
Why can’t the liver – in an individual with type 2 diabetes – decrease hepatic glucose when blood glucose is elevated in the morning?
It is not clear how much blood glucose is regulated by the liver, pancreas, and within muscles
Suspected that cortisol plays an important role
Similarly, what dictates blood glucose variability in a metabolically healthy individual?

title: Insulin and Glycogen Stores
content: Insulin-mediated fat deposit into fat cells operates normally, suggesting normal function of insulin. Elevated level of insulin is due to difficulty “pushing” glucose into already full Glycogen stores. Ronesh uses the parking space analogy of muscle glycogen stores when educating patients. Refer to his lecture at Google at 6:24 where he discusses the parking lot model and at 29:50 where he explains gender disparity in fuel distribution. Elevated FFA is an early insulin signal inhibitor for glycogen storage.

title: Mechanistic Explanations of Insulin Resistance
content: Mechanistic explanations of insulin resistance (there may be more than one) [35:15]. And there may not be one cycle, because I think I was trying to find one process flow that would explain all these cases. There could be multiple. We can see arrows and diagrams going in multiple directions. And I realized at a certain point that I need to understand this process, but I’m probably not going to figure it out exactly for each individual patient. There are different categories of insulin resistance that will apply to different patients, although the mechanistic explanations are not well understood. Peter focuses on hyperinsulinemia. He educates his patients about the endocrine system, explaining four: Thyroid system, Adrenal system, sex hormone, fuel partitioning. Can simplify fuel partitioning problem by looking at one element of it in hyperinsulinemia.

title: OGTT and CGM
content: Relies on (oral) glucose tolerance test (OGTT), using Glucola – which has limitations (not reflective of physiologic glucose disposal), but is a standardized comparison model. Peter hopes for better point-of-care insulin testing and mentions that developments are being done in this space to further improve the glucola-type test. CGM provides a measure of glycemic response in a real-world setting (whereas OGTT is taken in the morning, not in response to what a patient would ordinarily consume to spike blood glucose).

title: Theories on Origins and Evolutionary Reasons for Insulin Resistance
content: There have been different theories around the origins of insulin resistance. James Neel first proposed the Thrifty Gene Hypothesis. Insulin resistance is a result of human ancestors living in feast/famine cycles. The Barker Hypothesis is not based on an actual gene but a gene phenotype. Intrauterine environment (in-utero stress) can trigger insulin resistance and heart disease. Dr. C.S. Yajnik proposed the Soldier to Diplomat Hypothesis in which insulin resistance is an evolutionary adaptation that allows humans to preserve more glucose for brain function. Gerald (Jerry) Reaven who coined the term “metabolic syndrome” agreed that there is likely an evolutionary reason to preserve glucose for brain function. Dr. Yajnik’s research supports that hyperinsulinemia in utero may have some adaptive function to facilitate brain function and cognition (has positive trophic impact).

title: Refeeding after carbohydrate restriction
content: Postprandial elevated blood glucose after a fast/carbohydrate restriction is an evolutionary response to refuel the brain. Testable hypotheses: if muscle is resistant to insulin or if there is a delayed pancreatic response.

title: Metabolic disease in Asian populations
content: Asian populations seem to skip the obesity phenotype on their way to becoming metabolically dysregulated. South Asian population genetically have decreased pancreatic β-cell density. Lean (low amount of subcutaneous fat) habitus Asian populations still present with metabolic dysfunction.

title: Brown adipose tissue and insulin resistance
content: Brown adipose tissue is heat-generating (metabolically active), mitochondrially-dense, and can remove glucose from the system. There is an inverse relationship between the amount of brown adipose tissue and rates of insulin resistance in human populations. Populations in northern, colder climates require a more active thermogenic metabolism. Studies that compare the brown adipose tissue of South Asians and Europeans reveal that South Asians have significantly less brown adipose tissue.

title: Metabolic phenotypes within the Indian subcontinent
content: Between the northern and southern regions of India, there are marked differences in rates of insulin resistance, amount of brown adipose tissue, and body morphology. Northern populations near the Himalayas have low incidence of insulin resistance. Southern Indian populations near the equator have higher rates of insulin resistance.

title: Insulin Resistance and Vitamin D
content: Although there are confounders such as diet and activity level differences between populations, studies done on more rural, physically active southern populations still reveal relatively high rates of insulin resistance. Vitamin D levels, hyperinsulinemia, and other effects. A lot of vitamin D deficiency Ronesh sees in South Asian patient populations is due to their skin pigment. Population is both vitamin D resistant and individuals do not absorb enough. South Asians may not be adapted to have high vitamin D levels. Even though vitamin D helps with glucose disposal, he has not observed significant glycemic improvements with supplementation.

title: Vitamin D Supplementation
content: If he does supplement vitamin D for patients in the single digit ng/ml, Ronesh anecdotally has observed that supplementing vitamin D improves C-reactive protein (anti inflammatory benefits), helps with hypertension as patient blood pressures improve, and has a high placebo effect on energy levels with supplementation. Ronesh is hesitant to supplement aggressively due to high rates of coronary calcification that he sees in the treatment population. Peter no longer replaces vitamin D in his patients to achieve 40-60 ng/ml. He wants his patients to be above 30 ng/ml without supplementation. He personally no longer supplements with vitamin D.

title: Uric Acid and Blood Pressure
content: Although Peter has not observed that vitamin D supplementation lowers blood pressure, he focuses on decreasing uric acid. The effect of uric acid on blood pressure is significant. Decreasing uric acid content lowers blood pressure (uric acid hypothesized to be an evolutionary adaptation to increase blood pressure). Does not suggest antihypertensive medication until uric acid is below 5mg/dl. Correcting uric acid levels does not correct hyperinsulinemia.

title: Fructose and Uric Acid
content: The evolutionary benefit of being able to turn fructose into fat (and the price we are now paying for it). One hypothesis that the progressive loss of uricase activity allowed our ancestors to readily accumulate fat via the metabolism of fructose from fruits and survive harsh (and fruitless) winters. However, in today’s society, the intake of fructose, primarily in the form of added sugars, has skyrocketed, while the intake of natural fruits high in vitamin C has fallen. One byproduct of the conversion of sugar into fat is uric acid.

title: VO2 Max and Insulin Resistance
content: In a weight, age-matched control trial, a study reported hyperinsulinemic individuals have a lower VO2 max. In early states of insulin resistance the muscle becomes inefficient at oxidative phosphorylation (marked by high levels of resting lactate). In a study of lean individuals with a family history of diabetes, without signs of insulin resistance, and normal glucose tolerance, their VO2 max is already decreased. Offspring with a family history of diabetes had a 5% ATP output in response to VO2 max test compared to the 90% ATP output of individuals without a family history of diabetes. ATP output suppression suggests early mitochondrial dysfunction prior to signs of metabolic disease. Root cause of mitochondrial dysfunction for healthy offspring individuals with a family history of insulin resistance is not clear.

title: Lower cardiorespiratory fitness and reduced capacity to oxidize fat
content: One study suggests lower cardiorespiratory fitness (submaximal VO2 max) and reduced capacity to oxidize fat (fatty acid utilisation) represents a defect in substrate delivery to muscle, rather than in mitochondrial capacity to oxidise lipids (no marker for abnormal mitochondrial biogenesis).

title: Mitochondrial dysfunction and diabetes
content: The suppressed ATP output of diabetic offspring individuals compared to control (individuals that do not come from a family history of diabetes) suggests that their mitochondria does not catalyze ADP to ATP across the inner membrane in the same way. Suggests mitochondria preferentially undergoes aerobic glycolysis (Warburg Effect). It is still not clear if mitochondrial dysfunction is causal for diabetes or if it is an early, secondary symptom that precedes mitochondria gene expression.

title: Zone 2 fitness test to evaluate mitochondrial performance
content: Using a Zone 2 fitness test to evaluate mitochondrial performance. Compared to a Vo2 Max test, a Zone 2 fitness test test more accurately assesses mitochondrial efficiency. VO2 max test can be trained for (and via weight management). Test is not diluted by anaerobic metabolism involved in VO2 max test.

title: VO2 max test vs Zone 2 fitness test
content: A VO2 max test maximizes aerobic capacity but also involves anaerobic metabolism. Typically uses three minutes stages at increasing power output until failure (measuring real-time VO2). A zone 2 fitness test uses lactate as a proxy to clamp lactate in order to assess maximum ATP production. Samples lactate after long stage time interval (10-15 minute) on fixed power setting on a treadmill or bike. Produces a lactate performance curve. Lactate threshold is in the 3.8 to 4.2 millimolar range and the performance curve remains below this range (below aerobic threshold).

title: Exercise for long-term functional health
content: In his insulin resistant Asian patients with lean body morphologies, Ronesh emphasizes balancing physical activity that builds aerobic endurance without compromising muscle mass. Exclusive or predominant weight training facilitates increased glycogen storage capacity but patients became cardiovascularly deconditioned without doing other kinds of exercise. He observed that cardiovascular deconditioning had impact on further improvements in insulin resistance and glucose tolerance. Ronesh observes lean Asian patients more readily lose muscle mass than other ethnic groups when doing volume endurance training. As an explanation, studies in athletes reveal AMPK inhibition of mTOR but Ronesh hypothesizes that the threshold for mTOR inhibition may be lower in an Asian patient population.

title: Components of Exercise
content: It is important to incorporate at least four components of exercise: Stability, Strength, Cardio (aerobic and anaerobic). Peter favors a combination of zone 2 training and anaerobic training.

title: Importance of Building Stability and Strength
content: Ronesh emphasizes the importance of building stability and strength in his younger patients. By the time individuals in the Asian population reach 50-60 years of age, their leg strength is compromised.

title: Stress Management Exercises
content: To accommodate the schedules of busy professionals, Ronesh tries to integrate strength, mobility and stress management exercises throughout the day. Introduces apps and tools to measure the number of squats, stretching and balance exercise. Using a smart watch, Ronesh teaches breathing exercises to lower blood pressure. Tracking heart rate makes the case that individuals can act in ways to change their own physiology.

title: Insulin Resistance and PCOS
content: Ronesh observes insulin resistance in response to stress across different lifespans: from pre-diabetes, coronary heart disease, and polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Endocrinologists in the surrounding Bay Area report seeing 25% to 30% of Asian Indians who probably have some manifestation of PCOS. PCOS is the result of hyperinsulinemia. The effects of insulin on the ovary Theca cells results in release of testosterone. Many cases have been reversed with lifestyle changes that act to lower insulin. IGF plays a role but addressing hyperinsulinemia can reverse the condition and its manifestations.

title: Adiposity Phenotypes
content: Adiposity purely from excessive energy intake: given unlimited access to food, some people will just not be able to stop eating (they respond to caloric restriction). Adiposity coupled with hyperinsulinemia: Population subset that responds really well to carbohydrate restriction and intermittent fasting. The sleep, stress dysregulated group: Overweight individuals that do NOT respond to caloric restriction, carbohydrate restriction, or fasting (these tend to be mostly female).

title: Peter's Treatment Regimen for Sleep, Stress Dysregulated Group
content: Nutritional guidelines: Time restricted feeding, period fasting, carbohydrate restriction. In this case he will also increase monounsaturated fats and decrease saturated fats. Sleep = at least 8 hours per night. Exercise = Huge emphasis on daily exercise. Must identify what is driving stress response which is driving metabolic dysfunction. Approach requires patient’s commitment because it is a long process (may not see immediate drastic results). May not display as hypercortisolemia but there is often Inflammation (slightly elevated fibrinogen and CRP). Thyroid dysfunction (pre TSH there are thyroid antibodies marker).

title: Inflammation and Adiposity
content: Addressing insulin resistance may not be enough. Inflammation causes subcutaneous fat cell expansion and impacts the ability of the fat cell to release FFAs. This review describes the role of proinflammatory cytokines and hormones released by adipose tissue in generating the chronic inflammatory profile associated with visceral obesity. Increased subcutaneous adiposity could be evolutionary safety belt to have subcutaneous fat stores necessary to procreate. After menopause, insulin resistance phenotype becomes more prevalent.

title: Stress, Sleep, and Adiposity
content: Although difficult to measure, stress and sleep quality has effects on adiposity and overall health. Sleep efficiency is key. Many devices (Apple watch, Fitbit, WHOOP,  Oura Ring) can measure sleep duration. There is a large difference in health metrics between patients that get 6 versus 8 hours on average per night. In his South Asian patients, Ronesh sees a correlation between insulin resistance and sleep apnea. Patients don’t necessarily have a high BMI. Sleep apnea and intermittent hypoxia is an inflammatory stimulus. When sleep apnea is corrected via lifestyle changes or CPAP, glucose numbers decrease. Ronesh hypothesizes that hyperinsulinemia plays a causal role in sleep apnea.

title: Culture of Achievement and Adiposity
content: The way we raise our kids early on might actually set a pattern for how much of an accelerated life or how much of a stressed out nervous system they might have later on. As I’ve talked to more and more families who are in Silicon Valley, I’m realizing that it is a lot of the behavioral patterns that we’re instilling in our kids are kind of setting the foundation for insulin resistance and inflammation early on. -Ronesh

title: Manifestation of adult health disease early on in life
content: In his Silicon Valley patient population, Ronesh sees the manifestation of adult health disease early on in life. From fatty liver to adult hypertension in teenagers. Ronesh does not see a very strong relationship between coronary (heart) disease and elevated LP-a. Although published studies on LP-a suggests that the South Asian population are at risk for elevated LP-a, Ronesh does not observe a correlation. In fact, he sees plenty of heart disease in South Asians with normal LP-a levels.

title: How culture, family dynamics, and parenting styles impact health
content: Ronesh encourages patients to come into treatment with their families (kids), which gives him insight into family dynamics and stressors. Children are raised with the concept of “pyramid parenting”: The upcoming generation should exceed the achievement of their parents. Opioid and substance abuse has increased in response to achievement pressures. Ronesh and his wife present a talk that addresses the amount of pressure children are put under. Ronesh thinks this problem can be found anywhere. Snowplow parenting is another phenomenon in which parents create “pseudo profiles” of their children – projecting and creating large goals and aspirations that puts further pressure on children. Ronesh has experienced achievement pressure himself (his immigrant father became a doctor).

title: Tips for parents to help their kids better manager stress/be happier in the long run
content: Hobbies without expectations: Ronesh emphasizes the importance of instilling hobbies for stress reduction later in life. Specifically, a source of pleasure that is separate from pressure and expectation. Teach them to avoid too much internal rumination: Teach them how to cognitively reframe situations (and avoid internal rumination). As a parent, express some of your own thoughts and frustrations: Doing this in front of your kids might make them more free and comfortable to open up and tell you relatable stories from their own life.

title: Ron's thoughts on phones and screens for kids
content: Ronesh sees phone use as a drug or toxin and suggests delaying it as long as possible. He speaks to parents about the effect of device use on neurochemistry, dopamine pathways, and how it encourages social comparison. Ronesh is in the process of creating a non-profit called DATA (Doctors Against Tech Addiction) in which he could congregate the support of CEOs and entrepreneurs from high tech companies and physicians alike. Ways to curb your child’s usage of the device include finding a replacement for their idle time, planning activities without phones, and associating with other parents who agree with you and are willing to get together in a device-free environment.

title: How you can help yourself, your family, and your community without being an MD or PhD
content: Peter emphasizes that people don’t necessarily need a doctor to walk them through making big impacts on their health. There are so many resources (books, blogs, podcasts) that can help you improve your own health (stress, sleep, nutrition, etc.). Ronesh highlights a key point: People can still make a huge impact on the lives of their coworkers, their family, and friends just with the knowledge they’ve gained through the resources that Peter just mentioned. And it’s very rewarding to do so. And you can be an evangelist for health without being an MD or PhD.
